node.title: FDA Authorizes Pfizer Booster Shots for 16- and 17-Year-Olds, CDC Will Have Final Say
node.alt: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has officially authorized Pfizer's COVID-19 booster shot for 16- and 17-year-olds. Above, a group of teenagers serving as COVID-19 Student Ambassadors joined Governor Gretchen Whitmer to receive a dose of the Pfizer vaccine at Ford Field during an event to promote and encourage Michigan residents to get their vaccines on April 6, 2021, in Detroit.
node.description: This potential advancement comes as 5 million children ages 5 to 11 are expected to be at least partially vaccinated by the end of the week.
node.content:
["The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has officially authorized Pfizer's COVID-19 booster shot for 16- and 17-year-olds.", "The Pfizer-BioNTech booster is expected to expand usage, but the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) must formally recommend usage in order for teens to receive it. Those affected by the potential expansion will be able to receive the dose only if it has been six months since their second Pfizer shot.", "The Pfizer vaccine is currently the only one available to children and teens. Vaccinations for 5-year-olds and up began in November. Around 5 million 5- to 11-year-olds will have gotten the first dose by the end of this week.", "A formal decision by the CDC on whether or not to approve Pfizer's booster expansion is expected to be released soon.", "", "
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has officially authorized Pfizer's COVID-19 booster shot for 16- and 17-year-olds. Above, a group of teenagers serving as COVID-19 Student Ambassadors joined Governor Gretchen Whitmer to receive a dose of the Pfizer vaccine at Ford Field during an event to promote and encourage Michigan residents to get their vaccines on April 6, 2021, in Detroit.
", "The U.S. and many other nations already were urging adults to get booster shots to pump up immunity that can wane months after vaccination, calls that intensified with the discovery of the worrisome new omicron variant.", "The extra-contagious Delta variant is causing nearly all COVID-19 infections in the U.S., and in much of the world. It's not yet clear how vaccines will hold up against the new and markedly different Omicron mutant. But there's strong evidence that boosters offer a jump in protection against delta-caused infections, currently the biggest threat.", "Complicating the decision to extend boosters to 16- and 17-year-olds is that the Pfizer shot\u2014and a similar vaccine made by Moderna\u2014have been linked to a rare side effect. Called myocarditis, it's a type of heart inflammation seen mostly in younger men and teen boys.", "Health officials in Israel, which already gives boosters to teens, have said the side effect continues to be rare with third doses.", "A U.S. study this week offered additional reassurance. Researchers from children's hospitals around the country checked medical records and found the rare side effect usually is mild and people recover quickly, while COVID-19 itself can cause more serious heart inflammation. The research was published Monday in the journal Circulation.", "The Associated Press contributed to this report."]
